title: Ghana Meteorological Authority (Amendment) Bill
summary:
The Ghana Meteorological Authority (Amendment) Bill transforms the Ghana Meteorological Agency into a statutory authority with significantly expanded powers and a novel self-funding mechanism. The Authority will provide weather forecasting and meteorological services across aviation, agriculture, water management, and other sectors while ensuring compliance with international meteorological standards. The bill establishes a governing board comprising ministerial representatives, presidential appointees, and the Director-General, with mandatory regional offices in each regional capital.

**The most consequential provision is the National Meteorological Fund**, which draws revenue from multiple economic sectors through mandatory contributions: percentages of aviation landing and over-flight charges, airport taxes, construction project costs, oil production revenues, fisheries registration fees, maritime cargo charges, harbor dues, and agricultural insurance premiums. While this creates financial sustainability for the Authority, **it imposes new costs on businesses across aviation, maritime, oil and gas, construction, fisheries, and agriculture sectors**. Companies in these industries will see increased operational costs as they contribute to the Fund, with the specific percentage rates to be determined by regulations. The Fund will support meteorological research, training, equipment maintenance, and publicity activities.

The bill introduces a **mandatory licensing regime for all meteorological service providers and weather-related businesses**, requiring annual licenses that can be suspended or revoked for non-compliance, fraud, or substandard equipment. License applicants must undergo background checks, and companies must prove their officers have no criminal records. The Authority gains **broad powers to enter private property** to inspect meteorological equipment and remove obstructions affecting weather data collection, with compensation for damages but limited advance notice requirements. These property access powers can be delegated to District Assemblies, potentially creating inconsistent enforcement across regions.

**Business Environment Impact**: The bill affects multiple sectors through Fund contributions and licensing requirements, increasing compliance costs and regulatory oversight. **Digital Innovation**: The licensing regime may create barriers for weather technology startups and data service providers. **Privacy Concerns**: Property entry powers, while focused on equipment inspection, grant government officials access to private premises with minimal procedural safeguards. **Accountability**: The bill includes internal audit requirements, Auditor-General oversight, conflict of interest provisions for board members, and an appeals tribunal for licensing disputes, providing some checks on Authority powers. The Minister retains policy directive authority over the Board and must approve tax exemptions (subject to Parliamentary approval) and borrowing arrangements.

description.analysis:
The Ghana Meteorological Authority (Amendment) Bill creates substantial barriers to digital innovation in the meteorological services sector through a combination of monopolistic data control and comprehensive licensing requirements. The Authority's designation as "the sole authority to approve the establishment of meteorological stations" effectively creates a government monopoly over the foundational infrastructure for weather data collection. This monopoly extends to data processing and dissemination, with mandatory data sharing requirements for any approved stations. For the digital innovation ecosystem—including weather apps, agricultural technology platforms, climate analytics startups, and IoT weather sensor companies—this concentration of control over the primary data resource represents a fundamental constraint on competitive innovation and product differentiation.

The mandatory licensing regime compounds these challenges by requiring annual licenses for anyone providing "meteorological data services" or engaging in "any business connected with the provision of meteorological services." This broad language captures virtually all weather-related digital services, from consumer weather apps to enterprise climate risk analytics platforms. The licensing process involves background checks including criminal history investigations, facility inspections, and compliance with unspecified Board-determined conditions, creating regulatory uncertainty that particularly disadvantages startups and early-stage companies. The annual renewal requirement imposes ongoing compliance costs and regulatory risk, while the 60-day processing time can delay product launches and market entry. For technology entrepreneurs and investors, this regulatory environment increases both the cost and risk of innovation in meteorological services.

The cumulative effect is a restrictive framework that will likely slow the development of Ghana's weather technology sector and digital meteorological services ecosystem. While the bill doesn't prohibit private innovation entirely, it establishes the Authority as both regulator and competitor, controlling access to essential data resources while also providing consultancy services and developing equipment. International weather technology companies may find the licensing requirements and data access constraints unattractive, potentially limiting foreign investment and technology transfer. Domestic startups face the dual challenge of navigating an uncertain regulatory approval process while competing with a government authority that controls the underlying data infrastructure. This regulatory approach contrasts with global trends toward open meteorological data and light-touch regulation of weather technology services, potentially positioning Ghana at a competitive disadvantage in attracting digital innovation investment in this sector.

The Ghana Meteorological Authority (Amendment) Bill significantly deteriorates the business environment through mandatory financial contributions and expanded regulatory requirements that affect multiple economic sectors. The National Meteorological Fund imposes substantial new operational costs on businesses across aviation, maritime, construction, oil and gas, fisheries, and agricultural insurance sectors, with contribution rates ranging from 1% to 10% of various revenue streams, charges, and contract values. These are not voluntary fees but legally mandated contributions that will directly reduce profit margins and increase costs for companies operating in Ghana. For example, construction companies must contribute both 1% of tax-exclusive contract costs and an additional 2.5% of pre-tax contract value, while shipping companies face a 10% levy on gross freight revenue. Oil producers must pay 3% per barrel of crude oil produced. These cumulative costs will likely be passed on to consumers or reduce business competitiveness, potentially discouraging investment in affected sectors.

Beyond financial burdens, the bill introduces a comprehensive licensing regime that creates regulatory barriers and compliance costs for meteorological service providers and weather-related businesses. The requirement for annual licenses, background checks including criminal history investigations, facility inspections, and proof of clean records for all company officers adds administrative complexity and recurring costs. The one-year license validity period means businesses must navigate this compliance process annually, creating ongoing uncertainty and resource demands. This regime may particularly disadvantage startups and smaller companies in the growing weather technology and data services sector, potentially stifling innovation and competition in meteorological services.

The Authority's broad powers to enter private property for equipment inspection and obstruction removal, delegable to District Assemblies, introduce operational uncertainties and potential inconsistencies in enforcement across regions. The offence provisions that hold directors and officers personally liable for company contraventions create additional legal risks for business leadership. While the bill includes some accountability mechanisms such as an appeals tribunal and audit requirements, these do not offset the fundamental increase in regulatory burden, operational costs, and compliance complexity. The overall effect is a substantially more challenging business environment that increases costs, creates barriers to entry, and expands government oversight across multiple economic sectors, potentially reducing Ghana's attractiveness for business investment and entrepreneurship in affected industries.

keyConcerns.title: Vague Licensing Requirement Threatens Weather Tech Innovation
keyConcerns.description: The requirement to license "any business connected with meteorological services" is dangerously undefined and could capture weather apps, agricultural advisory platforms, and climate analytics startups. This licensing barrier doesn't exist in comparable democracies where weather data services are treated as ordinary commercial activities. The vague scope gives the Authority discretionary power to determine which digital services need licenses, creating regulatory uncertainty that will chill innovation in weather technology and data services.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Multi-Sector Tax Without Business Protections
keyConcerns.description: The bill imposes substantial mandatory contributions on seven economic sectors—aviation, construction, oil/gas, fisheries, maritime, and agriculture—ranging from 1% to 10% of revenues or contract values, with no exemptions for small businesses, phase-in periods, or hardship provisions. Construction projects face double taxation (1% + 2.5% of contract value), and agricultural insurance providers pay twice (5% from the Pool and 5% from individual providers). These new costs will increase operational expenses across Ghana's economy, potentially making some businesses unprofitable, with startups and SMEs facing disproportionate cash flow pressures.

keyConcerns.title: Government Monopoly on Weather Technology Innovation
keyConcerns.description: The Authority becomes the "sole authority to approve the establishment of meteorological stations," requiring government permission for any private weather monitoring equipment and mandating data sharing with the Authority. Combined with mandatory licensing for all weather-related businesses, this creates a regulatory monopoly that blocks market entry for weather technology startups, IoT sensor companies, and private data services—sectors where private innovation typically flourishes in developed economies.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Licensing Stifles Weather Tech Innovation
keyConcerns.description: All weather-related businesses must obtain annual licenses with undefined "terms and conditions" set by the Board, creating significant barriers for weather technology startups and climate data platforms. The Authority conducts criminal background checks and facility inspections with broad discretion but no clear disqualification criteria. This licensing regime exceeds typical OECD practice where weather services operate without mandatory licensing, potentially blocking innovation in agricultural weather apps, climate data platforms, and meteorological technology.

keyConcerns.title: Criminal Liability for Undefined Future Regulations
keyConcerns.description: The bill makes it a criminal offense to violate any "regulations, rules, orders or directives" issued by the Authority—even though these haven't been written yet. Corporate directors, officers, and partners are automatically held personally liable for violations by their organizations unless they can prove they took all reasonable steps to prevent it. This means business leaders face potential criminal prosecution for breaking rules they cannot currently know or anticipate, creating severe compliance uncertainty across aviation, maritime, construction, agriculture, and other affected sectors.

provisions.title: Establishment of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This law creates the Ghana Meteorological Authority as an official body. The Authority can own property, make contracts, and can acquire land needed for its operations, bearing any associated costs.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) There is established by this Act,  the Ghana Meteorological Authority as a body corporate.

- The Authority may for the performance of the functions of the Authority acquire

and hold property, dispose of property and enter into any contract or  related transaction .

(3) Where there is an hindrance to the acquisition of land, the land  may be acquired for the Authority under the Lands Act, 2020 (Act 1036) and the cost shall be borne by the Authority.

provisions.title: Object of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority's job is to provide weather services for the country. It also ensures that meteorology practices in the country meet international standards.
provisions.rawText: 2. The object of the Authority is to provide meteorological services in the country and ensure the operation and maintenance of international standards and practices in meteorology in the country.

provisions.title: Functions of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority is responsible for providing weather forecasts and meteorological information to various sectors like aviation, agriculture, and water management. It also manages weather stations, conducts research, and collaborates with international organizations to ensure accurate and reliable weather data and services. Additionally, the Authority ensures compliance with international meteorological standards and advises the government on meteorological matters.

provisions.title: Governing body of the Authority.
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision establishes the Authority's governing board, which includes the Minister, the Director-General, representatives from various ministries and organizations, and presidential appointees. The President must consider relevant expertise when appointing members to the board. This ensures that the Authority is guided by a diverse group of knowledgeable individuals.

provisions.title: Functions of the Board
provisions.plainLanguage: The Board is responsible for making sure the Authority's goals are met and that international weather standards are followed. It also manages the National Meteorological Fund and creates policies to help the Authority work effectively.

provisions.title: Tenure of office of members of the Board
provisions.plainLanguage: Board members, excluding the Director-General, serve three-year terms and can be reappointed once. Members can resign by writing to the President through the Minister, and they will be removed if they miss three consecutive meetings without a valid reason. If a member resigns, is removed, or dies, the President will appoint a replacement.
provisions.rawText:
6. (1)  A member of the Board shall hold office for a period of three years and is eligible for re-appointment for another term only.

(2)  Subsection (1) does not apply to the Director- General or any other person who is a member of the Board  by virtue of office.

(3)  A member of the Board other than the Director-General may, at any time by letter addressed to the President through the Minister, resign from office.

(4)  A member of the Board, other than the Director-General who is absent from three consecutive meeting of the Board without sufficient cause ceases to be a member of the Board.

(5) A member may, at any time, resign from office in writing addressed to the President through the Minister.

(6)Where a member of the Board is for sufficient reason, unable to act as a member of the Board, the Minister shall determine whether the inability would result in the declaration of a vacancy.

(7) Where there is a vacancy

(a) under subsection (3),(4), (5) or subsection (2) of section 8,

(b) as a result of a declaration under subsection (6), or

(c) by reason of the death of a member, the Minister shall notify the President of the vacancy and the President shall appoint a person to fill the vacancy.

provisions.title: Meetings of the Board.
provisions.plainLanguage: The Board must meet at least every three months, and special meetings can be called if requested by one-third of the members. Decisions are made by a majority vote, with the chairperson having a tie-breaking vote. The Board can also invite people to attend meetings, but they cannot vote.
provisions.rawText:
7. (1) The Board shall meet at least once every three months  for the conduct of business at a time and place determined by the chairperson.

(2) The chairperson shall, at the request in writing of not less than one-third of the membership of the Board, convene an  extraordinary meeting of the Board at a time and place determined by the Board.

(3) The quorum at a meeting of the Board is seven members.

(4) The chairperson shall preside at meetings of the Board  and in the absence of the chairperson, a member of the Board elected by the members present from among their number shall preside.

(5) Matters before the Board shall be decided by a majority of members present and voting and in the event of equality of votes, the person presiding shall have a casting vote.

(6) The Board may co-opt a person to attend a  meeting of the Board but that person shall not vote on a matter for decision at the meeting.

(7) The proceedings of the Board shall not be invalidated  because of a vacancy among the members or by a defect in the appointment or qualification of a member of the Board.

(8) Subject to this section, the Board shall determine the procedure for its meetings of the Board.

provisions.title: Disclosure of interest
provisions.plainLanguage: This section requires board members to disclose any personal interests they have in matters before the board. If a conflict exists, the member cannot participate in discussions or decisions on that matter. Failure to comply can lead to removal from the board and the recovery of any benefits obtained through the conflict.
provisions.rawText:
8. (1) A member of the Board who has in interest in a matter for consideration

              - (a) shall disclose in writing the nature of the interest and the disclosure shall form part of the record for the consideration of the matter; and

              - (b) is  disqualified  from  being  present  at  or  participating  in  the  deliberations  of  the Board except in respect of that matter.

(2) A member ceases to be a member of the Board if the member if that member has an interest in the matter before the Board and

(3) Without limiting any further cause of action that may be instituted against the member, the Board shall recover any benefit derived by a member who contravenes subsection(1) in addition to the revocation of the appointment of that member.

provisions.title: Establishment of committees
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows the Board to form committees to help with its work, and these committees can include people who are not on the Board. Committees made up entirely of non-Board members will only provide advice. Board committee members are subject to the same rules as Board members.
provisions.rawText:
9. (1) The Board may establish a committee consisting of members of the Board and nonmembers of the Board or both to perform a function of the Board.

(2) A committee composed of members and non-members of the Board shall be chaired by a member of the Board.

(3) A Committee of the Board composed of non-members only is advisory.

- Section 8 applies to members of a committee of the Board.

provisions.title: Organisation and operation of the National Framework for Climate Services 10. The Minister shall be responsible to
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision tasks the Minister with setting up and running the National Framework for Climate Services. This includes creating committees of experts and government officials to help guide the framework's operation. The goal is to ensure a coordinated and effective approach to climate services.

provisions.title: Offices of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority is required to open offices in each regional capital. It can also open other offices within a region if the Board approves. These offices will carry out specific tasks assigned by the Authority.
provisions.rawText:
11. (1) The Authority shall establish regional offices of the Authority in the regional capitals.

(2) The Authority may establish other offices within a region as the Board may determine.

(3) An office established by the Authority shall perform the functions determined by the Authority.

provisions.title: Allowances
provisions.plainLanguage: Board and committee members will receive allowances as compensation. The amount of these allowances must be approved by the Minister, in consultation with the Minister for Finance. This ensures proper authorization and financial oversight of the compensation.
provisions.rawText: 12. Members of the Board and members of a committee shall be paid allowances approved by the Minister in consultation with the Minister for Finance.

provisions.title: Policy directives
provisions.plainLanguage: The Minister can instruct the Board on policy matters. The Board is required to follow these instructions.
provisions.rawText: 13. The Minister may give directives to the Board on matters of policy and the Board shall comply

provisions.title: Director-General of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The President will appoint a Director-General for the Authority. This person will be the chief executive and their specific job details will be outlined in their appointment letter.
provisions.rawText:
14. (1) The President shall, in accordance with article 195, appoint a Director- General for the Authority.

(2) The Director-General

              - (a) is the chief executive of the Authority; and

              - (b) shall hold office on terms and conditions specified in the letter of appointment .

provisions.title: Functions of the Director-General
provisions.plainLanguage: The Director-General manages the Authority's daily operations, puts the Authority's decisions into action, and reports to the Board. They can assign tasks to other officers but remain responsible, and they also represent Ghana at the World Meteorological Organization.
provisions.rawText:
15. (1) The Director-General is

                - (a) responsible for the day to day administration of the Authority;

                - (b) responsible for the implementation of the decisions of the Authority; and

                - (c) answerable to the Board.

(2) The Director-General shall perform any other function assigned by the Board.

(3) The Director-General may delegate a function to an officer of the Authority but is not relieved of the ultimate responsibility for the performance of the delegated function.

(4) The Director-General shall be the permanent representative of Ghana to the World Meteorological  Organization  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  Regulation  6  of  the  World Meteorological Organization, Basic Document No. 15.

provisions.title: Principal officers of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Director-General of the Authority will have two deputies and other key staff to help manage operations. The President will appoint these deputies and principal officers, taking into account recommendations from the Board and the Public Services Commission. This ensures a structured leadership team for the Authority.
provisions.rawText:
16. (1) The Director-General shall be assisted by two Deputy Directors-General and other principal officers as the Board may determine.

(2) The President shall in accordance with the advice of the Board given in consultation with the Public Services Commission appoint the two Deputy Directors-General and other principal officers of the Authority.

provisions.title: Secretary to the Board.
provisions.plainLanguage: The head of legal services will serve as the Secretary to the Board. The Secretary is responsible for organizing meetings, keeping records, and handling other tasks assigned by the Board and Director-General. This person must be a lawyer with less than 10 years of experience.

provisions.title: Appointment of other Staff
provisions.plainLanguage: The President appoints the Authority's staff, as per constitutional guidelines. The Board can hire experts and consultants recommended by the Director-General. These appointments are made following the advice of the Board and the Public Services Commission.
provisions.rawText:
18. (1) The President shall in accordance with article 195, appoint other officers and staff of the Authority necessary for the effective and efficient performance of the functions of the Authority.

(2) The Board may on the recommendations of the Director-General engage the services of experts and consultants as the Board may determine.

(3) The appointment of officers of the Authority shall be made by the President in accordance with the advice of the Board given in consultation with the Public Services Commission and upon such terms and conditions as the appointing authority shall determine.

provisions.title: Funds of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority's funds come from several sources, including money allocated by Parliament, fines collected under this law, and donations or loans received. The Authority can also generate funds through investments and other internal activities.

provisions.title: Bank account of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision states that the Authority must have a bank account to hold its money. The account needs to be approved by the Controller and Accountant-General. This ensures proper financial oversight of the Authority's funds.
provisions.rawText: 20. Money for the Authority shall be paid into a bank account opened for the purpose with the approval of the Controller and Accountant-General.

provisions.title: Administrative expenses of the Authority
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision means the Authority's administrative costs will be paid for by the government through the Consolidated Fund. Essentially, taxpayer money will fund the Authority's operations. This ensures the Authority has the financial resources to function.
provisions.rawText: 21. The administrative expenses of the Authority shall be a charge on the Consolidated Fund.

provisions.title: Internal Audit Unit
provisions.plainLanguage: This section establishes an internal audit unit within the Authority to ensure financial accountability. The unit will conduct regular audits and report its findings to the board. The Authority must also submit annual reports and have its accounts audited by the Auditor-General.
provisions.rawText:
22. ( 1) The Authority shall have an Internal Audit Unit in accordance with section 83 of the Public Financial Management Act, 2016 (Act 921).

(2) The Internal Audit Unit shall be headed by an Internal Auditor who shall be appointed in accordance with the Internal Audit Agency Act, 2003 (Act 658).

(3) The Internal Auditor is responsible for the internal audit of the Authority.

(4) The Internal Auditor shall, subject to subsections (3) and (4) of section 16 of the Internal Audit Agency Act, 2003 (Act 658), at intervals of three months

                    - (a) a prepare and submit to the Board, a report on the internal audit carried out during the period of three months immediately preceding the preparation of the report; and

                    - (b) make recommendations in each report, with respect to matters which appear to  the  Internal  Auditor  as  necessary  for  the  conduct  of  the  affairs  of  the Authority.

(5) The Internal Auditor shall, in accordance with subsection 4 of section 16 of the Internal  Audit  Agency  Act, 2003 (Act 658),  submit a copy of each report prepared under this section to the Director-General and the chairperson of the Board

Accounts and audit

23. (1) The Board shall keep books, records and returns of account and other documents relevant  to accounts in a form approved by the Auditor-General.

(2)  The  Board shall submit the accounts of the Authority to the Auditor-General within three months after the end of the financial year.

(3)  The  Auditor-General  within  six  months  after  the  end  of  the  immediately  preceding financial year, audit the accounts of the Authority and forward a copy each of the audited report to the Minister and the Board.

(4) The financial year of the Authority is the same as the financial year of the government.

Annual report and other reports.

24. (1) The Board shall within thirty days after receipt of the audit report, submit an annual report to the Minister covering the activities and operations of the Authority for the year to which the annual report relates.

(2)The annual report shall include the report of the Auditor-General.

(3) The Minister shall within two months after receipt of the annual report, submit the report to Parliament with a statement that the Minister considers necessary.

(4) The Board shall submit to the Minister any other report which the Minister may require in writing.

provisions.title: Borrowing powers
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows the Authority to borrow money from different entities with the Finance Minister's approval, following specific financial regulations. To secure these loans, the Authority can use its assets as collateral. This enables the Authority to obtain funding for its operations or projects.
provisions.rawText:
25. (1) Subject to article 181 of the Constitution and section 76 of the Public Financial Management Act, 2016 (Act 921) and with prior consent in writing of the Minister responsible for Finance, the Authority may borrow money from a body corporate, financial market or any other person,

(2) For the purposes of securing the money borrowed, the Authority may mortgage, charge or pledge a right, title or an interest in any of the properties of the Authority.

provisions.title: Tax exemption
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Authority to be exempt from paying certain taxes. The specific taxes that are exempt will be determined by the Minister, but only with the approval of Parliament. This exemption is subject to the constitution and other relevant laws.
provisions.rawText:
26. Subject to article 174 of the Constitution and the Exemptions Act 2022, Act ( 1038) the Authority is exempt from the payment of taxes that the Minister, may in writing, determine, with the prior approval of Parliament.

## National Meteorological Fund

provisions.title: Establishment of the National Meteorological Fund
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision creates the National Meteorological Fund. The fund's purpose will be defined in further sections of the bill, likely related to supporting meteorological activities.
provisions.rawText:
27. There is established by this Act the National Meteorological Fund.

Objects of the Fund

28. …………………………………….

provisions.title: Application of moneys for the Fund
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority's funds will be used for publicity, research, training, and maintaining its properties. The funds can also be used for other activities that support the Authority's goals, as decided by the Board in consultation with the Minister. This ensures the Authority has the resources to promote its work and achieve its objectives.

provisions.title: Sources of money for the Fund
provisions.plainLanguage: The Fund receives money from a variety of sources, including fees and charges related to the Authority's functions, percentages of aviation landing and over-flight charges, airport taxes, construction project costs, oil production, fisheries registration, maritime cargo, harbor dues, agricultural insurance premiums, meteorological training, investments, loans, grants, and donations. These diverse revenue streams ensure the Fund has a stable financial base to support its objectives.

provisions.title: Bank account for the Fund
provisions.plainLanguage: The Fund's money will be deposited in a bank account created by the Board. The Controller and Accountant-General must approve this bank account. This ensures proper oversight of the Fund's finances.
provisions.rawText: 31. The moneys for the Fund shall be paid into a bank account opened by the Board for the purpose with the approval of the Controller and Accountant- General.

provisions.title: Payments from the Fund
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision mandates that all payments from the Fund must be made via cheque. The Director-General is responsible for signing these cheques. This ensures accountability and a clear record of all financial transactions.
provisions.rawText:
- All payments from the Fund shall be by cheque and signed by

            - (b) the Director-General.

provisions.title: Management of the Fund
provisions.plainLanguage: The Board manages the Fund by creating financial policies, deciding how the money is spent, and setting yearly goals. Sections 23 and 24 also apply to the Fund. This ensures the Fund is used effectively to achieve its objectives.
provisions.rawText:
## 33. (1) The Fund shall be administered by the Board.

    - The Board shall for the purpose of administration of  the Fund

                - (a) formulate policies to generate money for the Fund;

                - (b) determine the allocation to be made towards the objects of the Fund; and

                - (c) determine annual targets of the Fund.

    - Sections 23 and 24 apply to the Fund.

provisions.title: Investment of the Fund
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Board to invest some of the Fund's money in securities to potentially increase its value. However, the Minister responsible for Finance must approve these investment decisions. This ensures responsible management and oversight of the Fund's assets.
provisions.rawText:
## 34. The Board may invest a part of the Fund as it considers appropriate in securities as the Minister responsible for Finance .

## Licensing and Related Matters

provisions.title: Requirement for licence to operate
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision mandates that anyone offering weather data services, acting as a weather agent, running a weather-related business, or engaging in weather transactions must obtain a license from the Authority. This ensures that all weather services are provided by licensed and regulated providers.
provisions.rawText:
- A person shall not

          - (a) provide meteorological data services,

          - (b) provide services as a meteorological agent,

          - (c) engage in any business connected with the provision of meteorological services, or

          - (d) engage in meteorological transactions

unless that person has obtained a license to operate as a Meteorological Services Provider or Agent from the Authority.

provisions.title: Application for a licence
provisions.plainLanguage: To become a licensed weather service provider or agent, you must apply to the Authority using their official form. Companies, societies, associations, or partnerships must also prove their officers have no criminal records. Depending on the situation, a fee may be required to examine equipment.
provisions.rawText:
## 36. (1) A person shall apply to the Authority for a licence as a Meteorological Service Provider or Agent.

    - An application for a licence shall

                - (a) be made to the Authority in the form determined by the Board;

                - (b) in the case of a company, society, association or partnership be accompanied with an attestation that officers of the company, society, association or partnership do not have any criminal record; and

                - (c) where appropriate, be accompanied with the prescribed fee for the examination of equipment.

provisions.title: Conditions for grant of a licence
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority can grant a license to an applicant who fulfills all the requirements it has established. These requirements for obtaining a license will be made public by the Authority. This ensures transparency and allows individuals to understand what is needed to qualify for a license.
provisions.rawText:
37. ( 1) The Authority may issue a licence to a person if the person has met all the requirements determined by the Authority.

- The Authority shall publish the requirements for application for the licence.

provisions.title: Grant of licence
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority will conduct background checks on license applicants and must grant a license within 60 days if the applicant meets the requirements. The license will include the licensee's name and address, the issue date, and will be valid for one year. The license is also subject to terms and conditions set by the Board.

provisions.title: Non-transferability of licence
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision means that a license issued under this law cannot be transferred to another person or entity. The license is only valid for the individual or organization to whom it was originally granted.
provisions.rawText: 39. A licence issued under this Act is not transferable.

provisions.title: Renewal of licence
provisions.plainLanguage: A license can be renewed if the application is submitted within 30 days of expiration, includes required documents and fees, and complies with the original license terms. The renewal application must also meet the same standards as the initial license application.

provisions.title: Suspension of licence
provisions.plainLanguage: The Authority can suspend a meteorological service provider's license if they fail to perform their duties or if they don't fix issues after being notified. Before suspension, the provider must receive notice, be informed of the reasons, and have a chance to respond.
provisions.rawText:
41. (1) The Authority may suspend the licence of a meteorological  service provider or agent or where the Authority determines that the meteorological agent has failed to perform the function specified in the licence.

(2) The Authority shall suspend the licence, if the Authority

            - (a) gives at least ten days' notice to the service provider or agent whose licence the Authority intends to suspend;

            - (b) states in the notice the grounds for the suspension;

            - (c) serves on the service provider or agent a copy of any complaint or charges which the Authority proposes to consider; and

            - (d) gives the agent, the opportunity to be heard either in person or be represented by a

(3) The Authority shall suspend the licence of a meteorological service provider or Agent who, after being given notice, fails to take the required remedial action within the specified time.

provisions.title: Revocation of licence
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Authority to revoke a license if it was obtained fraudulently, the agent commits a serious crime, the agent makes fraudulent misrepresentations, or the agent's equipment is substandard. This ensures agents operate honestly and maintain appropriate standards. The revocation is subject to the rules outlined in the Act.

provisions.title: Restoration of licences
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision ensures that a license will be restored if the licensee follows the Authority's instructions. It means a previously suspended or revoked license can be reinstated if the licensee complies with the Authority's directives. This provides a pathway for licensees to regain their standing by meeting the necessary requirements.
provisions.rawText: 43. The Authority shall restore a licence if the licensee complies with the directives issued by the Authority.

provisions.title: Appeals to the Tribunal
provisions.plainLanguage: If the Authority suspends, revokes, or refuses to grant a license, the applicant can appeal to the Appeal Tribunal. The Tribunal's decision is final, meaning it cannot be appealed further. This process allows applicants a chance to challenge unfavorable licensing decisions.
provisions.rawText:
44. (1) An Applicant who is aggrieved by  a decision of the Authority in respect of a suspension, revocation or refusal to grant a licence shall appeal to the Appeal tribunal .

(2) The decision of the tribunal shall be final and binding.

provisions.title: Confidentiality
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires members and employees of the Authority to keep information they obtain confidential, unless a court or law requires them to disclose it. Violating this confidentiality can result in disciplinary action, including removal from the Board.
provisions.rawText:
45. (1) A member of the Board, the Director-General, or any other officer or employee of the Authority shall

      - (a) subject to any existing law, treat as confidential any information obtained in the exercise of powers or the performance of duties under this Act; and

      - (b) not disclose any information except when required to do so by a court, under any enactment or other circumstances determined by the Board.

(3) Any person who contravenes to subsection (1) shall be subject to disciplinary action, and in the case of a member of the Board be liable to be removed from the Board.

provisions.title: Improper use of the official seal of the organisation
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision makes it illegal to use the World Meteorological Organization's official seal, emblem, or name without the Minister's permission. Violators will be fined and may have related goods confiscated. This protects the organization's identity and prevents misuse of its symbols.
provisions.rawText:
46. (1) A person shall not, without the authority of the Minister use

      - (a) the official seal and emblem of the World Meteorological Organisation as specified in the schedule; or

      - (b) the designation "World Meteorological Organization" or an abbreviation of that designation.

(3) A  person  who  contravenes  subsection  (1)  commits  an  offence  and  is  liable  on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding 200 penalty units and shall forfeit to the Republic the goods in connection with which the seal, emblem or designation was used.

provisions.title: Offences
provisions.plainLanguage: This section defines offenses under the Act, including violations of its rules and regulations. It holds directors, officers, and partners responsible for offenses committed by their organizations, unless they can prove they were not involved and took steps to prevent the violation. This ensures accountability for compliance with the Act's requirements.
provisions.rawText:
47. ( 1) A person shall not

              - (b) contravenes the regulations, rules, orders or directives issued under any of the provisions of this Act;

- A  person  who  contravenes  subsection  (1)  commits  an  offence  is  liable ....................................................

Offences  by a body of persons

48. (1) Where  an offence is committed by a body of persons

                  - (a) in the case of a body corporate, every director or officer of that body corporate shall be deemed to have committed that offence; and

                  - (b) in the case of a partnership or a firm, every partner of the partnership or firm shall be deemed to have committed that offence

(2) A person shall not be deemed to have committed an offence under subsection (1), if that person proves that the act  in respect of which  that person is charged was committed by some other person without the consent  or connivance of that person and that the person exercised all due diligence to prevent the commission of the offence having regard to all the circumstances.

## Miscellaneous Provisions

provisions.title: Power to enter land or premises
provisions.plainLanguage: This section allows authorized officers to enter properties to inspect meteorological equipment, remove obstructions, and ensure accurate weather data collection. Property owners will be notified beforehand, and the Authority will compensate for any damages caused during the process. This power can be delegated to local District Assemblies.
provisions.rawText:
## 49. (1) For the purpose of carrying out a function under this Act, an officer of the

Authority may, after giving notice to the owner or occupier of any land or premises, enter the land or premises and do any act reasonably necessary for carrying out the function and in particular may

              - (a) inspect and examine a land, building or equipment of meteorological stations;

              - (b) inspect  and  examine  accounts,  records  and  memoranda  required  to  be  kept  by meteorological stations;

              - (c) cut down and remove any tree, underwood or structure that  may interfere with surveys; and

              - (d) remove  any  installation  which constitutes a hindrance  to the delivery of meteorological climate in consultation with the Environmental Protection Authority.

(2) The Authority shall pay compensation for any damage caused as a result of action taken under subsection (1), and the liability for and the amount of  the compensation shall in case of dispute be settled in the first instance by negotiation.

(3) The Authority may delegate a power under this section to the relevant District Assembly.

provisions.title: Execution of contract
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision details the signing process for Authority contracts. The Director-General authenticates the Authority's seal, and the Director-General or a board member can sign other contracts if authorized. This process is also subject to the Contracts Act of 1960.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) The use of the seal of the Authority shall be authenticated by the signatures of (a) the Director-General; and

- An instrument or contract which if executed or entered into by a person other than a body corporate would not require to be under seal, may be executed or entered into on behalf of the Authority by the Director-General or any member of the Authority if the person has previously been authorised by a decision of the board to execute or enter into that particular agreement or contract.

- This section is subject to section 12 of the Contracts Act, 1960 (Act 25).

provisions.title: Regulations
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Minister to create regulations on various aspects of meteorology. These regulations can include guidelines for climate requirements, the establishment of weather stations, fees, aeronautical services, weather observation standards, and licensing requirements. This gives the Minister the power to set rules and standards in these areas.

provisions.title: Interpretation.
provisions.plainLanguage: This section provides definitions for terms used in the Ghana Meteorological Authority Act, such as "Authority," "meteorology," and "sectoral activities." These definitions ensure clarity and consistent understanding of the Act's provisions. It essentially serves as a glossary for the legal document.

provisions.title: Repeal and savings
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision repeals the old law governing the Ghana Meteorological Agency. It also ensures that any existing agreements or actions taken under the old law remain valid even after the new law takes effect. This prevents any disruption to the agency's operations.
provisions.rawText:
53. (1) The Ghana Meteorological Agency Act, 2004 (Act 682) is hereby repealed.

(2)  Notwithstanding the repeal under subsection (1) any contracts, orders or decisions or anything made or done by a body which until the coming into force of this Act, was charged with the performance of any of the functions under this Act shall, be valid and continue in force as if it was made or done under this Act.

provisions.title: Transitional provisions
provisions.plainLanguage: This section transfers all assets, rights, and responsibilities from the old Ghana Meteorological Agency to the new Ghana Meteorological Authority. Current employees will keep their jobs under similar terms, and existing contracts will remain valid. People with old licenses can apply for new ones under the new Authority.
provisions.rawText:
54. (1) The rights, assets, and liabilities that have accrued in respect of the properties vested in Ghana Meteorological Agency in existence immediately before the coming into force of this Act shall be transferred to the Ghana Meteorological Authority established under this Act.

(2)  A person in the employment of the Ghana Meteorological Agency immediately before the coming into force of this Act, shall on the coming into force of this Act, be deemed to have been duly employed by the Ghana Meteorological Authority established under this Act on the terms  and  conditions  which  are  not  less  favourable  in  aggregate  to  the  terms  and  conditions attached to the post held by the person before the coming into force of this Act.

(3)  A  contract subsisting between the Ghana Meteorological Agency and another person and in effect immediately before the coming into force of this Act shall subsist between the Ghana Meteorological Authority and that other person subject to modifications that are necessary to ensure compliance with this Act.

(4) A person whose license ceases to be valid under the Ghana Meteorological Agency may apply to the Ghana Meteorological Authority under this Act.
